he risks are mounting against Fonterra holding its current forecast milk payout and this week's GlobalDairyTrade auction could be yet another nail in its coffin.

item.title: Fonterra shareholders simmer while embattled company paints brighter future at AGM - New Zealand Herald
item.description:
Fonterra shareholders simmer while embattled company paints brighter future at AGM  New Zealand Herald

Fonterra's new leadership is being given the benefit of the doubt by its long-suffering farmer-shareholders, but further financial blunders won't be tolerated.

item.title: Fonterra raises milk prices, moves to scrap Bonlac supply agreement - ABC News
item.description:
Fonterra raises milk prices, moves to scrap Bonlac supply agreement  ABC News

Fonterra Australia, the local arm of New Zealand's largest milk processor, has raised its forecast average milk price and revealed it will end its agreement with the Bonlac Supply Company. Fonterra Australia acquired the Bonlac co-operative in 2003, signing a supply agreement with its 1,100 farmers at the time which said Fonterra had to match rival Murray Goulburn's farmgate milk price. The suppliers are the largest group within the Fonterra Australia supply base and use their position to collectively bargain with the processor. A new agreement could be put to a vote at the company's Annual...

item.title: Tasmanian dairy farmers confidence 'shaky' despite price clarity from buyer - ABC News
item.description:
Tasmanian dairy farmers confidence 'shaky' despite price clarity from buyer  ABC News

Tasmanian dairy farmer's confidence in the major milk processors remains "shaky", despite yesterday's move by dominant player Fonterra to clarify next year's farm gate prices, the state's peak farming body says. The dairy giant announced on Wednesday afternoon it planned to increase the price it pays suppliers, from between $4.75 and $5.30 per kilogram of milk solids, to between $5.30 and $5.70 for the 2017/2018 season. On top of that, Fonterra has offered an additional 40 cents per kilogram to current or returning suppliers. Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association (TFGA) Dairy Council C...

item.title: Bellamy's dumps CEO, slashes profit guidance - ABC News
item.description:
Bellamy's dumps CEO, slashes profit guidance  ABC News

Tasmanian infant formula manufacturer Bellamy's shares have slumped by more than a third after it dumped its chief executive and slashed its profit guidance for the coming six months. Bellamy's shares had slumped 34 per cent to $4.39 by 2:15pm (AEDT), after the company resumed trade. Five things to know about the baby-formula company going sour The company emerged from a 40-day trading halt on Wednesday afternoon, and announced an overhaul of its leadership team. The board announced CEO Laura McBain had been replaced by chief operating officer and chief strategy officer Andrew Cohen. During...

item.title: Murray Goulburn reveals milk prices for the coming season - ABC News
item.description:
Murray Goulburn reveals milk prices for the coming season  ABC News

Australia's largest milk processor, Murray Goulburn, has revealed it expects to pay its suppliers between $5.20 to $5.40 per kilogram of milk solids (kgms) by the end of the 2017-18 financial year. In a statement released on Tuesday morning the processor said it would start the season with an opening farmgate milk price of $4.70 kgms. Murray Goulburn produces the Devondale line of products, as well as trading in bulk commodity products and supplying ingredients for adult and infant formula. Dairy farmers in the south east of Australia had become used to seasons where processors announced an...

item.title: Dairy company Fonterra offers an opening price of $5.30 - ABC News
item.description:
Dairy company Fonterra offers an opening price of $5.30  ABC News

New Zealand dairy company Fonterra has announced an opening season price of an average of $5.30 per kilogram of milk solids (kgms) for the 2017-18 season to dairy farm suppliers. The company has also upgraded its forecast closing range by 10 cents to $5.40 to $5.80. Fonterra is the last of the major milk processors to release its opening prices, and is offering a higher price than major competitor Murray Goulburn, which announced their opening price of $4.70 with a closing range of $5.20 to $5.40 over a week ago. This follows on from Bega Cheese and Warrnambool Cheese and Butter which both ...

item.title: Legal action dropped against Murray Goulburn but continues against Fonterra - ABC News
item.description:
Legal action dropped against Murray Goulburn but continues against Fonterra  ABC News

A class action against dairy processor Murray Goulburn has been dropped after the company agreed to abandon its clawback of money from farmers. The company this week announced it would close three factories, drop its controversial clawback of farmer payments, and borrow money to artificially keep its milk price higher if required. Audio: Lawyer David Burstyner explains what decisions from dairy companies mean for possible legal action (ABC News) Farmers have applauded the decision to forgive the clawback money, which is officially referred to as the Milk Supply Support Package (MSSP). The p...

item.title: Bellamy's update worsens board-shareholder stand-off - ABC News
item.description:
Bellamy's update worsens board-shareholder stand-off  ABC News

The Bellamy's trading update has left as many questions open as it answered, with the troubled company again being punished on the share market as a result. Key points: - Bellamy's shares down 15pc to $4.53 by 12:55pm (AEDT) - Dissident shareholder group continuing with moves to spill most of the board - Analysts remain cautious given the uncertainties around Bellamy's future After 40 days of trading in its shares being halted or suspended, the stock plunged 20 per cent yesterday after forecasting a fall in annual profit of as much as two-thirds. The pain continued today, with Bellamy's sha...

item.title: Fonterra suppliers the forgotten farmers of the dairy crisis - ABC News
item.description:
Fonterra suppliers the forgotten farmers of the dairy crisis  ABC News

It has been one year since the forgotten farmers of the dairy crisis, those who supply Fonterra, learnt they would have their milk price cut too. Eight days after Murray Goulburn cut its price, farmers who send their milk to Fonterra were informed of sudden and retrospective milk price cuts. For the last year Fonterra suppliers, Bridget and Tim Goulding have been paying more to produce milk than what they're getting paid for it. "It's been a horrible year," Bridget Goulding said. "You know, you've found within yourselves, when you work together as a couple there are always going to be argum...

item.title: Milk processors, farmers nearing code of conduct deal on prices - ABC News
item.description:
Milk processors, farmers nearing code of conduct deal on prices  ABC News

Dairy farmers and milk processors are close to sealing a deal for a new voluntary code of conduct on milk price contracts, with all but fresh milk giant Lion having indicated they are prepared to sign. Audio: Dairy code deal close, John McQueen from Australian Dairy Farmers (ABC News) The code of conduct would provide farmers with greater pricing transparency, clearer contracts and forewarning of price cuts. Instead of sudden and retrospective milk price cuts like the ones delivered to Murray Goulburn and Fonterra suppliers in Autumn last year, processors would have to give notice to farmer...

item.title: Government extends loan scheme to NDP suppliers - ABC News
item.description:
Government extends loan scheme to NDP suppliers  ABC News

The Federal Government has bowed to pressure and extended its dairy concessional loan scheme to include National Dairy Products (NDP) suppliers. NDP retrospectively cut its farm gate milk price alongside other dairy processors earlier in the year. Suppliers then staged a mass exodus from the company after the company failed to pay them for milk. NDP is now in voluntary administration and dozens of dairy farmer suppliers across Victoria are owed millions of dollars. Since the company's collapse, suppliers and lobby group United Dairyfarmers of Victoria had made repeated appeals to the Minist...

item.title: Murray Goulburn milk supply drops 22 per cent, with further drops expected - ABC News
item.description:
Murray Goulburn milk supply drops 22 per cent, with further drops expected  ABC News

Dairy processor Murray Goulburn will struggle to maintain the title of 'Australia's biggest', with its milk intake forecast to sit equal with New Zealand-owned rival Fonterra. Announcing its full year financial results this morning, Murray Goulburn revealed its milk intake had dropped nearly 22 per cent from the previous financial year to 2.7 billion litres, and was expected to drop even further over the coming season to 2 billion litres. "MG has experienced a difficult year as a result of the significant reduction in milk intake and adverse seasonal conditions," MG said in a statement to t...

item.title: Farmers disappointed with Senate report on dairy industry - ABC News
item.description:
Farmers disappointed with Senate report on dairy industry  ABC News

A long-awaited government review of how to fix the dairy industry's woes has left farmers feeling disappointed and dubious. Key points: - Report recommends ACCC look at ways to bolster code of conduct - Scrutiny of clawback clauses left to ACCC - Calls for collective bargaining to be made easier and independent review of dairy farmer support package - Farm groups encouraged to give members better legal advice on milk contracts Following last year's dairy crisis, the Senate Economics References Committee set out to establish a fair and long-term solution to improving everything from milk pri...

item.title: Bega Cheese forecasting further profit growth despite industry downturn - ABC News
item.description:
Bega Cheese forecasting further profit growth despite industry downturn  ABC News

Shares in dairy processor Bega Cheese fell more than 10 per cent as the company held its annual meeting. Chairman Barry Irvin confirmed the company's partnership with Blackmores to export infant formula to Asia hadn't gone as planned. He also reaffirmed a statutory after-tax profit of $28.8 million, up 132 per cent on the previous year. The profit came amid an industry price crisis, which was triggered when rivals Murray Goulburn and Fonterra suddenly, and retrospectively, cut prices. "The result of an oversupply of dairy products was continued downward pressure on dairy commodity prices," ...

item.title: Fonterra will not axe controversial repayment program - ABC News
item.description:
Fonterra will not axe controversial repayment program  ABC News

Fonterra has announced it will not follow Murray Goulburn's decision to axe its controversial repayment program. Instead, the dairy company announced on Wednesday, it would pay its farmers an additional 40 cents per litre of milk solids for the coming year. Managing director Rene Dedoncker said it was not an obligation but that it was the right thing to do. "Forty cents is the amount that resonates and will make a significant difference on-farm and will rebuild confidence [and] goes a long way for them to pay down those loans," he said. "We do acknowledge it won't satisfy every single farme...

item.title: Murray Goulburn lifts farmgate milk prices for the new season - ABC News
item.description:
Murray Goulburn lifts farmgate milk prices for the new season  ABC News

Milk processor Murray Goulburn has lifted its opening farmgate milk price for the coming milk season to $5.20 kilogram of milk solids (kgms). Its initial offering of $4.70 kgms was beaten by every other milk processor in south-eastern Australia. The $5.20 offering includes its 'reward program', payments Murray Goulburn is offering suppliers who've never left the cooperative or new suppliers. Murray Goulburn made that announcement on June 6, much earlier than it usually discloses its opening price. The processor refused an interview with the ABC, instead issuing a statement to media saying l...

item.title: Fonterra bids for Murray Goulburn - ABC News
item.description:
Fonterra bids for Murray Goulburn  ABC News

New Zealand-owned dairy giant Fonterra has confirmed it has made a bid for embattled milk processor Murray Goulburn. Managing director of Fonterra Australia Rene Dedoncker confirmed to ABC Rural that his company had made the bid while outlining the company's financial performance for the past year. "The answer is yes we have put forward a proposal," Mr Dedoncker said. "It's non-binding and indicative and at this point we are going to sit tight and give the MG board the respect they deserve to consider all proposals." Mr Dedoncker would not elaborate on any further details of the proposal bu...

item.title: Victorian dairy farmers owed millions, overlooked by government and feeling 'neglected and let down' - ABC News
item.description:
Victorian dairy farmers owed millions, overlooked by government and feeling 'neglected and let down'  ABC News

Most Australians are aware of the turbulent year Victorian dairy farmers have endured. Audio: Gippsland mother-of-three Fiona Plant says her family is owed hundreds of thousands of dollars by National Dairy Products. (ABC Rural) But few know the plight of Fiona Plant and a small group of others, who not only experienced retrospective price cuts earlier in the year, but are now facing the prospect they will not be paid a cent for months of milk already supplied. Ms Plant and her husband Linden have three children under seven years old and milk about 900 cows in their two Gippsland dairies. O...

item.title: Call for dairy pricing reforms after Murray Goulburn chief faces Senate inquiry - ABC News
item.description:
Call for dairy pricing reforms after Murray Goulburn chief faces Senate inquiry  ABC News

The dairy industry has been swift to react to the first public comments by the former head of Murray Goulburn during a Senate inquiry into the ongoing dairy price crisis. Gary Helou, via a teleconference on Wednesday, defended the decisions he and his former company made when it suddenly and retrospectively cut farmer milk prices. Mr Helou said authorities had not approached him in relation to allegations that Murray Goulburn had misled investors in its prospectus. External Link: Adam Jenkins tweet That shocked Adam Jenkins, the head of lobby group United Dairyfarmers of Victoria. He tweete...

item.title: Murray Goulburn awaits outcomes from inquiries - ABC News
item.description:
Murray Goulburn awaits outcomes from inquiries  ABC News

Despite multiple inquiries and talk of two separate class actions, Australia's largest dairy processor Murray Goulburn is yet to face direct consequences over its actions in the milk price collapse. But as suppliers and shareholders prepare for the Murray Goulburn annual general meeting this Friday, investigations into the dramatic and retrospective cuts to farm gate milk prices by Murray Goulburn and Fonterra are ongoing. At a Senate inquiry into the state of the dairy industry on Wednesday, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) told the committee it expected to deliver...

item.title: Dairy farmers accuse Fonterra of breaching new dairy code - ABC News
item.description:
Dairy farmers accuse Fonterra of breaching new dairy code  ABC News

Dairy giant Fonterra has been accused of breaching rules of a new code of conduct just over a month before it's put in place. Fonterra told its suppliers this week that it won't follow Murray Goulburn and axe its version of the controversial clawback loan scheme for farmers. Instead it has forecast a milk price of $5.30 to $5.70 per kilogram of milk solids for next season and says it will pay an extra 40 cents on top of that as a reward to farmers who continue to supply it, or pay a lump some to those who have retired. Farmers who left Fonterra to supply another company will get nothing. Vo...

item.title: Gas industry attempts to allay fears, as farmers push back against exploration - ABC News
item.description:
Gas industry attempts to allay fears, as farmers push back against exploration  ABC News

The gas industry is partly to blame for the increasingly negative community attitude to extraction and exploration in South Australia's south-east, a resources industry representative says. The controversial issue of gas exploration in the south-east has been ignited again with the State Government's energy plan, offering incentives of 10 per cent of royalties to landowners who allow their property to be explored for gas, if it results in a productive gas well. Last year a parliamentary inquiry found that fracking should not take place in the region because there was not a social licence to...

item.title: New Zealand dairy giant posts loss after China stake sours - The Associated Press
item.description:
New Zealand dairy giant posts loss after China stake sours  The Associated Press

WELLNGTON, New Zealand (AP) — New Zealand's largest company, which sells dairy products, said Thursday it will completely review its business investments after a disastrous financial year saw it post its first-ever loss. Fonterra lost hundreds of millions of dollars on its investments in China and also had to pay a large arbitration settlement following a 2013 botulism scare. The company has a new leadership team, which is promising to turn things around, after both the chief executive and board chairman recently quit. Fonterra is the world's largest exporter of dairy products and controls ...

item.title: Fonterra announces business shake-up after posting first annual loss - Financial Times
item.description:
Fonterra announces business shake-up after posting first annual loss  Financial Times

Fonterra has announced a major shake-up of its business, including a strategic review of its troubled Chinese joint venture, as the world’s biggest dairy exporter slumped to its first ever annual loss. New Zealand’s biggest company said on Thursday it would re-evaluate all investments, major assets and partnerships to ensure they still met its needs. It follows a disastrous 12 months, which have seen its shares drop to near-record lows over concerns about governance, execution of strategy and its Chinese joint venture, Beingmate. “This (review) will involve a thorough analysis of whether th...

item.title: Fonterra shares near 3-year low after profit warning - Financial Times
item.description:
Fonterra shares near 3-year low after profit warning  Financial Times

Fonterra Cooperative Group cut the price it intends to pay farmers for milk and issued a profit warning on Friday, sending shares in the world’s biggest dairy exporter down to near three year lows. The world’s biggest dairy exporter said it is reducing last season’s forecast farm gate milk price by five cents to NZ$6.70 per kg of milk solids and warned its earnings would be at or slightly below its prior guidance of 25 – 30 cents per share. Fonterra said it is likely its full year dividend would be just the 10 cents already paid in April. “Our forecast performance is not where we expected i...

item.title: Dairy farmers plan to walk away from industry - ABC News
item.description:
Dairy farmers plan to walk away from industry  ABC News

Dairy farmer Steve Dalitz loves his cows and knows them all by name, but he is preparing to say goodbye to them. Mr Dalitz has made the tough decision to put his dairy farm on the market. "I'll miss the cows but one day I just decided it," he said. The combination of low milk prices and high feed and water costs have put enormous financial pressure on the Dalitz family. "None of our boys are interested in milking cows and I'm 50 now, and it's just getting harder and harder to make a living from it," he said. Photo: Steve Dalitz is a third generation dairy farmer. (ABC News: Lauren Day) With...

item.title: Fonterra Chairman resigns on health concerns - Reuters
item.description:
Fonterra Chairman resigns on health concerns  Reuters

Milk producer Fonterra (FCG.NZ: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz) said on Friday Chairman John Wilson has resigned from his position with immediate effect over concerns regarding his health. Fonterra's board has selected company veteran John Monaghan as the co-operative's new chairman. Monaghan has been on the dairy firm's board since 2008 and has played a key role in the search of a new chief executive, Fonterra said in a statement. "Within the last month Mr Wilson has undergone a significant surgery and will require on-going treatment," it added. Earlier this year, Fonterra had flagge...

item.title: Meet the cheesemaker who gets paid to make and taste 60 pizzas a day - ABC News
item.description:
Meet the cheesemaker who gets paid to make and taste 60 pizzas a day  ABC News

A cheesemaker from country Victoria has stumbled into a foodie's dream — what some might consider the world's best job. Paul Triste gets paid to make and taste 60 pizzas a day. His job is part of a small dairy farming community's bid to become the industry leader in a traditional Italian cheese. Four years ago, fire destroyed the primary cheese plant of Fonterra's operation in Stanhope, in northern Victoria. The company moved much of its cheese production to New Zealand while a $140 million rebuild got underway. More cheese, please Now, with a new cheese plant twice the size of the old one,...

item.title: Fonterra’s China partner warned over product mislabelling - Financial Times
item.description:
Fonterra’s China partner warned over product mislabelling  Financial Times

Fonterra’s partner in China has been hit with a warning over mislabelled products, in the latest blow for the New Zealand group that this year took a NZ$405m (US$275m) writedown on its Chinese investment. Beingmate, into which Fonterra paid $553m for a minority stake three years ago, has been warned by Chinese regulators that it had mislabelled an ingredient in its infant formula product. Fonterra is the world’s largest dairy exporter. The warning was widely reported in China, where parents have been extremely cautious about milk powder safety since 2008, when dairy company Sanlu— Fonterra’...

item.title: Dairy farmers walking away farms as confidence continues to fall - ABC News
item.description:
Dairy farmers walking away farms as confidence continues to fall  ABC News

Dairy farmers are looking at walking away from their farms, as the dairy crisis starts to impact according to a national confidence survey of dairy farmers. The annual national farmer survey of 800 farmers from around Australia, looked at farmer confidence, which showed that less than half of farmers surveyed remained confident about the industry's future. This figure has fallen from 75 per cent four years ago, and has been declining over the past three years. The confidence of farmers has not been recorded this low since 2013 when it was at 43 per cent, which was at a time when farm gate r...

item.title: Dairy farmers unite for better milk price and pool their milk - ABC News
item.description:
Dairy farmers unite for better milk price and pool their milk  ABC News

A group of Victorian dairy farmers is trying to reclaim bargaining power in a fight for a better milk price by offering processors a collective pool of milk. The farmers, based in northern Victoria, are extremely concerned about the future of the dairy industry and have decided to act and form a collective bargaining group, United We Stand. The group has fielded dozens of calls with interest from as far as Tasmania. External Link: UWS dairy farmers Facebook post In less than a month, the group has had 85 million litres of milk pledged from more than 40 farmers, who supply the major processo...

item.title: Meat, fish and dairy companies accused of not investing enough in alternative protein - Financial Times
item.description:
Meat, fish and dairy companies accused of not investing enough in alternative protein  Financial Times

The world’s leading meat, fish and dairy companies are putting long-term growth at risk by failing to invest in alternative protein businesses, according to an investor advisory and research network supported by asset managers worth $5.9tn. The Fairr initiative — Farm Animal Investment Risk & Return — says that only five out of 60 leading listed international food groups have backed plant-based meat alternatives grown in laboratories as well as dairy alternatives. These are Tyson Foods and Hormel Foods of the US, Canada’s Maple Leaf, China Mengniu Dairy and Vietnam Dairy. The organisation, ...

item.title: Fonterra chief to resign as China woes erase profits - Financial Times
item.description:
Fonterra chief to resign as China woes erase profits  Financial Times

Fonterra is to part ways with chief executive Theo Spierings after the world’s biggest dairy exporter slumped to a NZ$348m first-half loss due to problems at its Chinese partner. The New Zealand conglomerate said on Wednesday that Mr Spierings would step down before the end of the year. His departure follows criticism of governance at Fonterra by some of its 10,500 farmer shareholders, who have become increasingly concerned about the poor performance of Beingmate, a Shenzhen-listed infant formula maker. In 2015 Fonterra paid NZ$756m for an 18.8 per cent stake in Beingmate, which at the time...

item.title: Fonterra CEO to resign as China problems hit profits - Financial Times
item.description:
Fonterra CEO to resign as China problems hit profits  Financial Times

Fonterra said on Wednesday that chief executive Theo Spierings would step down before the end of the year as the world’s biggest dairy exporter slumped to a NZ$348m first-half loss due to problems at its Chinese partner Beingmate. The New Zealand company wrote down the value of its 18.8 per cent stake in Beingmate by NZ$405m to reflect the poor performance of the Chinese infant formula maker in which Fonterra bought an 18.8 per cent stake in 2015. A NZ$183m damages payment to French food giant Danone following a false botulism scare in 2013 also dented the conglomerate’s financial performan...

item.title: Fast Asia Open: Thailand trade data - Financial Times
item.description:
Fast Asia Open: Thailand trade data  Financial Times

US regulators are set to grill Facebook about how its user data were leaked to Cambridge Analytica, as the UK political consultancy suspended its chief executive. The Federal Trade Commission is asking the technology group for more information about how Cambridge Analytica, which worked for the Trump election campaign, obtained data of more than 50m Facebook users, according to people familiar with the matter. Facebook came under increased international scrutiny on Tuesday as two US state attorneys-general joined the FTC and European regulators in expressing strong concern over the revelati...

item.title: Fonterra’s second China foray comes under scrutiny - Financial Times
item.description:
Fonterra’s second China foray comes under scrutiny  Financial Times

When Fonterra, the world’s biggest dairy exporter, paid $553m for a minority stake in Chinese infant formula maker Beingmate, it represented a second run at the world’s largest formula market after its previous partner was shut down in a safety scandal. But the 2015 deal that it described as a “game changer” has turned sour. Its Chinese partner has lost 70 per cent of its market value in three years. Both companies have been critical of each other and some of Fonterra’s 10,500 farmer shareholders are questioning whether the co-operative should dump its investment. Beingmate was profitable w...

item.title: High stakes for trendy steakhouse Salt Bae - Financial Times
item.description:
High stakes for trendy steakhouse Salt Bae  Financial Times

A consortium formed of two large Singaporean funds — GIC and Temasek — and private equity firm Metric Capital, is close to buying a minority stake in a group of restaurants that include Nusr-Et Steakhouse, known for the social media phenomenon Salt Bae, the flamboyant Turkish chef. People who have worked closely with at least one of the Singaporean funds told DD’s Javier Espinoza that they wonder about the rationale of the deal when investors are looking to deploy huge sums of cash (the equity ticket on this would be just $200m) in one go. Others also questioned the timing because high stre...

item.title: Murray Goulburn takeover raises concerns with Australia's competition regulator - ABC News
item.description:
Murray Goulburn takeover raises concerns with Australia's competition regulator  ABC News

The competition watchdog says it would not approve the proposed $1.3 billion foreign takeover of Australian dairy co-operative Murray Goulburn in its present form, due to concerns for dairy farmers in Victoria's south west. The deal, announced last year, would see Canadian dairy giant Saputo acquire all of Murray Goulburn's assets and operating liabilities, subject to regulatory and shareholder approval. If the deal is successful in its proposed form, Saputo would control around three billion litres of raw milk supply in Victoria, about half of the state's total, and a third of the national...

item.title: A2 milk production to expand and diversify - ABC News
item.description:
A2 milk production to expand and diversify  ABC News

New Zealand dairy giant Fonterra has announced a partnership with its fellow milk processor The a2 Milk Company (a2) in a deal likely to make A2 milk more widely available. The Australian arm of Fonterra will set up an A2 milk pool to service its nutritional product range which is produced from its Darnum factory in Gippsland. Dairy farmers will need to be recruited in Australia who are able to supply the specialist milk which is sourced from cows that produce A2 beta-casein proteins in their milk. Fonterra will be working with their current Australian dairy suppliers and assist them transi...

item.title: a2 Milk, Seven Group and Fairfax stocks surge amid mixed results - ABC News
item.description:
a2 Milk, Seven Group and Fairfax stocks surge amid mixed results  ABC News

It was a day of mixed results and strong gains in share price for some of Australia's largest companies. Some of the notable strong performers today were a2 Milk, Seven Group Holdings and Fairfax (despite its fall in profit). Baby formula booms a2 Milk was the best performing stock on the ASX 200, surging 25.4 per cent to $10.92 just before 2pm AEDT. This was after the company announced its net profit jumped by 150 per cent to $91.9 million ($NZ98.5 million) on surging sales of infant formula in Australia and China. Sales of its a2 Platinum range totalled $341 million, which was 78 per cent...

item.title: Baby formula recalled worldwide over salmonella scare - CNN
item.description:
Baby formula recalled worldwide over salmonella scare  CNN

Baby formula is being pulled from shelves around the world after French authorities ordered a leading dairy company to stop selling hundreds of products because of concerns about food safety. French firm Lactalis is recalling formula destined for markets including China, Greece, Pakistan and Peru after 26 infants fell ill with salmonella poisoning in France. Lactalis was told earlier this month about an outbreak of salmonella poisoning among children who had consumed its products, but the steps it took weren't enough to bring the risk of contamination under control, France's top health and ...

item.title: Dairy producers mixed after auction prices snap losing streak - Financial Times
item.description:
Dairy producers mixed after auction prices snap losing streak  Financial Times

Shares in dairy producers listed in New Zealand were mixed on Wednesday after global wholesale milk prices improved for the first time in two months. The Global Dairy Trade index – the industry benchmark reflecting the latest fortnightly auction prices – lifted 0.4 per cent on Tuesday, including a 1.7 per cent rise in the price of whole milk powder. The improvement snapped a run of four straight declines for the index and marked a slight rebound from two weeks prior when the price of milk products dropped 3.4 per cent to an eight-month low. On the New Zealand stock market on Wednesday, Synl...
